hero.title: Mestej Winery
hero.subtitle: Crafting honey, buckthorn, and blueberry wines with tradition and care.

welcome.title: Welcome to Mestej!
welcome.description: Mestej Meadery stands at the intersection of ancient brewing traditions and modern craft innovation, creating exceptional meads that honor history while embracing contemporary palates.

aboutUs.title: About us
aboutUs.paragraph1: Mestej Meadery began as a vision to bring ancient brewing traditions in Eritrea/Ethiopia to a wider audience. Today Mestej Meadery offers a variety of mead alternatives with different flavors.
aboutUs.paragraph2: The name Mestej is simply a combination of the words, 'mes' and 'tej', which translates as mead, in Tigrinya and Amharic languages.

history.title: Our History
history.subtitle: Rooted in heritage, Mestej carries forward centuries of mead-making tradition.

origins.title: Ancient Origins
origins.paragraph1: No one knows exactly when Mes/Tej was first produced, but the earliest dated mention of the beverage is found in Aksumite writings. Aksum (Axum) was a kingdom that primarily encompassed today's northern Ethiopia and Eritrea, but during its peak, it dominated both sides of the Red Sea. The language spoken in Aksum was the now-extinct language, Ge'ez. It is also from the Ge'ez language that the word for honey wine, 'mes,' originated.
origins.paragraph2: In the book, Inscriptions de l'Ethiopie Antique, the Dutch scholar A.J. Drewes translates Aksumite texts about Mes/Tej written in Ge'ez. The texts show that it was primarily royalty and nobility who consumed Mes/Tej; it was served together with injera and various meat stews—a practice that continues to this day!

european.title: European Accounts
european.description: Later, during the 15th and 17th centuries, when several Europeans visited the region, they described Mes/Tej in a similar way to the translations from a thousand years earlier.

legacy.title: A Timeless Tradition
legacy.paragraph1: According to The Encyclopedia of World Environmental History, it is believed that Mes/Tej is among the oldest alcoholic beverages in the world.
legacy.paragraph2: Today, the drink is primarily consumed during various holidays and gatherings in Eritrea/Ethiopia. There are also traditional houses where mes/tej is served; they are called tej bet.

products.title: Our Meads
products.subtitle: Discover our handcrafted collection of traditional and innovative meads

meads.name: Buckwheat
meads.description: Buckwheat mead offers one of the most distinctive and polarizing flavor profiles in the mead world, known for its robust, earthy character that stands in stark contrast to lighter, floral honey varieties. Buckwheat mead represents the bold, unapologetic side of mead-making. It's not a beginner's mead, but rather a sophisticated choice for those seeking depth and complexity beyond typical honey wines. The intense earthy character can be challenging initially, but reveals remarkable complexity and nuance for those willing to explore its depths. This is a mead that commands attention and respect, offering a drinking experience that's both primitive and refined, simple yet profoundly complex.

optimalConditions.title: Optimal Conditions
optimalConditions.glassware: Use wide-bowled glasses to appreciate the complex aromas
optimalConditions.servingSize: Small servings recommended due to intensity

meads.name: Mestej
meads.description: Tej is a traditional Eritrean/Ethiopian honey wine that holds a special place in the local culture and cuisine. The careful balance of honey sweetness and gesho's herbal complexity creates a unique drinking experience that continues to evolve while maintaining its cultural significance. Whether enjoyed in a traditional Eritrean/Ethiopian home or discovered in international markets, tej offers a taste of Eritrean/Ethiopian heritage in every sip.

foodPairings.title: Food Pairings
foodPairings.subtitle: Perfect Pairings
pairings: Excellent with spicy Ethiopian dishes (balances heat well)
Pairs beautifully with hard cheeses and olives

meads.name: Buckthorn
meads.description: Buckthorn mead with gesho presents a bold, complex flavor profile that challenges and delights the palate with its unique combination of tart, tropical, and herbal elements. This combination represents one of the more adventurous mead styles, where gesho's traditional earthy character meets sea buckthorn's vibrant modernity. The result is a beverage that's simultaneously challenging and refreshing, offering layers of complexity that reveal themselves with each sip. The gesho provides the necessary structural elements to tame sea buckthorn's wild nature, creating a harmonious balance between intensity and elegance.

optimalConditions.title: Optimal Conditions
optimalConditions.serve: Serve well chilled (8-10°C/46-50°F) to balance the intensity
optimalConditions.glassware: Use tulip-shaped glasses to concentrate the complex aromas
optimalConditions.servingSize: Consider as an aperitif to stimulate the palate

foodPairings.title: Food Pairings
foodPairings.subtitle: Ideal Companions
pairings: Excellent with rich, fatty foods (the acidity cuts through fat)
Complements Asian cuisine, particularly Thai and Vietnamese
Pairs beautifully with seafood, especially scallops and shrimp
Wonderful with creamy cheeses or spicy dishes

meads.name: Blueberry
meads.description: Blueberry mead enhanced with Gesho (Rhamnus prinoides) offers a uniquely complex flavor profile that bridges African and Western traditions. This combination represents a fascinating fusion where North American berries meet traditional African brewing ingredients, creating a truly global mead experience that's both familiar and exotic. The gesho provides the structural backbone that elevates blueberry mead from a simple fruit honey wine to a complex, sophisticated beverage worthy of contemplation.

optimalConditions.title: Optimal Conditions
optimalConditions.glassware: Use wine glasses to concentrate aromas
optimalConditions.servingSize: Allow to breathe for 10-15 minutes before serving

foodPairings.title: Food Pairings
foodPairings.subtitle: Perfect Pairings
pairings: Excellent with grilled meats and roasted vegetables
Complements strong cheeses (blue cheese, aged cheddar)
